law.summary: Comprehensive AI governance framework that establishes disclosure requirements, prohibits harmful AI uses, regulates biometric data collection, and creates enforcement mechanisms. Focuses on prohibited practices rather than prescriptive governance requirements. Includes affirmative defenses for NIST AI RMF compliance and a regulatory sandbox program for testing innovative AI systems.

definitions.artificial_intelligence_system: Any machine-based system that, for any explicit or implicit objective, infers from the inputs the system receives how to generate outputs, including content, decisions, predictions, or recommendations, that can influence physical or virtual environments.
definitions.developer: A person who develops an artificial intelligence system that is offered, sold, leased, given, or otherwise provided in Texas.
definitions.deployer: A person who deploys an artificial intelligence system for use in Texas.
definitions.consumer: An individual who is a resident of Texas acting only in an individual or household context. The term does not include an individual acting in a commercial or employment context.
definitions.biometric_data: Data generated by automatic measurements of an individual's biological characteristics, including a fingerprint, voiceprint, eye retina or iris, or other unique biological pattern or characteristic used to identify a specific individual.

applicability.scope_conditions: Applies to AI systems developed or deployed in Texas for use with consumers, including systems used by governmental entities and healthcare providers. Specific prohibitions apply to AI systems that: (1) intentionally incite self-harm or criminal activity; (2) assign social scores; (3) collect biometric data without consent; (4) unlawfully discriminate against protected classes; or (5) produce illegal content.
exemptions: Third-party misuse of AI systems (safe harbor for developers/deployers)
Violations discovered through testing, red-teaming, or compliance with NIST AI RMF (safe harbor)
AI systems not yet deployed (safe harbor during development)
Financial institutions compliant with federal and state banking laws (sector-specific exemption)
Insurance entities subject to anti-discrimination statutes (sector-specific exemption)
Biometric data use for security, fraud prevention, or healthcare under HIPAA (purpose-specific exemption)
applicability.geographic_trigger: Developing or deploying AI systems in Texas OR offering AI systems to Texas consumers

obligations.requirement_text: A governmental agency that makes available an artificial intelligence system intended to interact with consumers shall disclose to each consumer, before or at the time of interaction, that the consumer is interacting with an artificial intelligence system.
obligations.plain_language: Government agencies must tell consumers when they're interacting with an AI system, even if it's obvious.

obligations.requirement_text: The disclosure required under Subsection (a) must be clear and conspicuous and written in plain language. A governmental agency may not use a dark pattern to obscure the disclosure.
obligations.plain_language: AI disclosure notices must be clear, easy to understand, and not hidden using deceptive design practices.

obligations.requirement_text: A person licensed under Subtitle B, Title 3, Occupations Code, or under Chapter 102, 103, 151, 201, 202, 203, 204, 351, 401, 402, 403, 451, or 507, Occupations Code, shall disclose to a patient not later than the date the service or treatment is first provided that an artificial intelligence system will be used or is being used to provide a health care service or treatment to the patient.
obligations.plain_language: Healthcare providers must disclose to patients when AI is being used for healthcare services or treatment, by the time service begins or as soon as reasonably possible in emergencies.

obligations.requirement_text: A person may not develop or deploy an artificial intelligence system in a manner that the person knows or reasonably should know is intentionally aimed to incite or encourage a person to: (1) commit physical self-harm, including suicide; (2) harm another person; or (3) engage in criminal activity.
obligations.plain_language: You cannot develop or deploy AI systems designed to encourage self-harm, violence against others, or criminal activity.

obligations.requirement_text: A person may not develop or deploy an artificial intelligence system in a manner that the person knows or reasonably should know is intentionally aimed to incite or encourage a person to: (1) commit physical self-harm, including suicide; (2) harm another person; or (3) engage in criminal activity.
obligations.plain_language: You cannot develop or deploy AI systems designed to encourage self-harm, violence against others, or criminal activity.

obligations.requirement_text: A governmental entity may not use or deploy an artificial intelligence system that evaluates or classifies a natural person based on social behavior or personal characteristics with the intent to calculate or assign a social score or similar valuation to the person or a group to which the person belongs that will result in detrimental or unfavorable treatment of the person or group, impose disproportionate punishment or discipline on the person or group, or infringe on a person's federal or state constitutional rights.
obligations.plain_language: Government agencies cannot use AI to assign 'social scores' that lead to unfair treatment or violate constitutional rights.

obligations.requirement_text: A governmental entity may not develop or deploy an artificial intelligence system for the purpose of uniquely identifying a natural person based on biometric data of the person without the person's informed and freely given consent if the unique identification will infringe on a person's state or federal constitutional or legal rights.
obligations.plain_language: Government agencies cannot use AI to identify people through biometric data without their informed consent if it would violate their rights.

obligations.requirement_text: A person may not intentionally develop an artificial intelligence system to unlawfully discriminate against a protected class in violation of state or federal law, including Chapter 21, Labor Code.
obligations.plain_language: You cannot intentionally develop AI systems to unlawfully discriminate against protected classes under state or federal law.

obligations.requirement_text: A person may not intentionally deploy an artificial intelligence system to unlawfully discriminate against a protected class in violation of state or federal law, including Chapter 21, Labor Code.
obligations.plain_language: You cannot intentionally deploy AI systems to unlawfully discriminate against protected classes under state or federal law.

obligations.requirement_text: A person may not intentionally develop an artificial intelligence system to produce an image or video depicting sexually explicit conduct that: (1) appears to be of a child; or (2) is a deep fake that impersonates or is intended to impersonate a child.
obligations.plain_language: You cannot develop AI systems to produce child sexual abuse material or deep fake sexual content impersonating children.

obligations.requirement_text: A person may not intentionally develop an artificial intelligence system to engage in text-based conversations that simulate or describe sexually explicit conduct and are designed to impersonate or imitate a child.
obligations.plain_language: You cannot develop AI systems that simulate sexual conversations while impersonating children.

obligations.requirement_text: On receipt of a consumer complaint submitted through the online mechanism established under Section 552.102, the attorney general may issue a civil investigative demand under Section 15.10, Business & Commerce Code. The attorney general shall provide written notice of a violation before bringing an action under this section. On receipt of a notice under this subsection, a person shall have 60 days to cure the alleged violation.
obligations.plain_language: If the Attorney General notifies you of a violation, you have 60 days to fix it before enforcement action is taken.

obligations.requirement_text: A person subject to regulation by a state agency that applies to test and deploy an AI system under the program must submit with the person's application: (1) a detailed description of the artificial intelligence system, intended benefits, and its impact; (2) a risk mitigation plan; (3) documentation regarding any compliance with a federal artificial intelligence law; and (4) any other information or documentation requested by the department.
obligations.plain_language: To participate in the regulatory sandbox program, you must submit detailed system documentation, risk mitigation plans, federal compliance records, and other requested information.

obligations.requirement_text: A program participant must submit quarterly reports to the department regarding performance metrics, risk mitigation, and feedback from users and stakeholders during the testing period.
obligations.plain_language: If participating in the regulatory sandbox, you must submit quarterly performance and risk reports to the Department of Information Resources.

penalties.penalty_range: $10,000 - $12,000 per curable violation; $80,000 - $200,000 per uncurable violation; $2,000 - $40,000 per day for continuing violations. State agencies may impose additional licensing sanctions up to $100,000.
penalties.notes: No private right of action. Enforced exclusively by Texas Attorney General under Tex. Bus. & Com. Code § 552.105. The AG must provide written notice of violation before bringing enforcement action. Upon receipt of notice, the person has 60 days to cure the alleged violation and must explain how the violation was cured and identify changes made to internal policies. The AG must establish an online consumer complaint portal by September 1, 2026. State agencies may impose additional sanctions (suspension, probation, revocation of licenses) for licensed/registered entities found in violation.

safe_harbors.description: Affirmative defense when third parties misuse the AI system in ways that violate TRAIGA. A developer or deployer cannot be found liable if someone else uses their AI system in a prohibited manner.

Affirmative defense when violations are discovered through feedback received from developers, deployers, or other persons; testing procedures such as red-teaming or adversarial testing; following state agency guidelines; or internal review processes.

Affirmative defense for entities that discover violations through internal review processes, provided the entity is otherwise in compliance with a nationally recognized AI risk management framework, such as NIST's AI Risk Management Framework.
Affirmative defense during development phase. AI systems that have not been deployed are protected from liability for potential violations discovered during development.

Regulatory sandbox program provides legal protection and limited market access to test innovative AI systems for up to 36 months without obtaining licenses or regulatory authorizations (except Subchapter B prohibitions remain enforceable).

cross_references.notes: Colorado AI Act is more prescriptive than TRAIGA, requiring impact assessments, consumer disclosures, and comprehensive documentation for high-risk AI systems making consequential decisions. TRAIGA takes a more innovation-friendly approach, focusing on specific prohibited practices rather than comprehensive governance requirements. Colorado requires deployers to conduct annual impact assessments; TRAIGA does not mandate impact assessments but provides safe harbors for NIST compliance.

California's ADMT regulations (under development by CPPA) will impose similar transparency and disclosure requirements for automated decision-making technology, including pre-use notice, opt-out rights, and access to logic explanations. Both jurisdictions focus on consumer protection but California's approach is more aligned with privacy law frameworks while Texas focuses on prohibited use cases.

TRAIGA amends and works alongside Texas's existing Capture or Use of Biometric Identifier Act (Chapter 503, Business & Commerce Code). TRAIGA clarifies that consent cannot be inferred solely from publicly available media unless the individual made it publicly available. Both laws require informed consent for biometric data collection.

Texas Data Privacy and Security Act (TDPSA) provides broader data privacy rights including access, correction, deletion, and portability. TRAIGA's AI-specific requirements work alongside TDPSA's general privacy protections. Both laws grant exclusive enforcement to the Texas Attorney General with no private right of action.

change_log.description: HB 149 (Texas Responsible AI Governance Act) signed into law by Governor Greg Abbott. Effective date set for January 1, 2026.

Enrolled version (HB 149F) significantly scaled back from original bill. Removed mandatory impact assessment requirements for deployers and high-risk AI system categorization. Shifted focus to specific prohibited practices and affirmative defenses.
House Committee on State Affairs amended original HB 149 to add regulatory sandbox program (Chapter 553) and clarify biometric data consent requirements under existing Chapter 503.
